entry.title: SAP UX Q3/2025 Update – Part 7: UI Design and Technology for Web and Mobile
entry.content:
This seventh and last post in my series gives an overview innovations in our UI tools and technologies, making it ever easier to design, build and integrate UIs, for both web and mobile applications. For designing apps, web and mobile, we have a new SAP Design System portal and UI Kits in Figma. For developers, we have added further AI assistance, as well as many individual improvements, including support for the latest international accessibility standard WCAG 2.2. Fun fact: SAPUI5 is now used on all 7 continents – yes, Antarctica too! 

Before reading this, do read the first blog post introducing the series and providing general information about Joule and central entry points and services, along with links to all the published parts of this blog post series:

  • SAP UX Q3/2025 Update – Part 1: AI, Joule, SAP Build Work Zone, SAP Mobile Start.

The above post also gives an update on building your own Joule agents, so I will not cover that here, but rather focus on web and mobile UI development.

 

Design News

SAP Design System Portal and UI Kits in Figma

We recently introduced the new SAP Design System portal that brings together the product design guidelines SAP Fiori for web, SAP Fiori for iOS, and SAP Fiori for Android, as well as to the new digital design system guidelines. With its enhanced usability, simplified versioning and improved performance, designers (and developers!) get a better user experience compared with the previous SAP Fiori design guidelines.

Figure 1: The SAP Design System portal start page. Alt Text: Image with header saying “SAP Design System”, with a “See what’s new” button below it, and then four subsections in a horizontal row: SAP Fiori for Web, SAP Fiori for Android, SAP Fiori for iOS and SAP’s Digitial Design System. A “Feedback” button is on the bottom right.

The new UI Kits available for designers in Figma make it easy for designers to design accessible UIs at enterprise scale, for web applications, mobile iOS and Android applications as well as wearables. The UI Kits provide reusable components for web and mobile, along with web floorplans, which give you what you need out-of-the-box.

Figure 2: SAP’s UI Kits for Designers in Figma. Alt-Text: The image shows two rows of four cards representing UI Kits: SAP Fiori for Android, SAP Fiori for Web, Designing for Performance, SAP Fiori for iOS, SAP Fiori for watchOS, SAP Fiori for Wear OS, SAP S/4HANA for Web, and Accessibility Design Tools. On the very left of the image information about SAP is listed, with links to resources such as www.sap.com/design-system.

Find out more here:

  • New SAP Design System Portal for SAP Fiori Design Guidelines, and New UI Kits for Designers.

Design Updates for the SAP Business Suite

Consistency of the user experience across the various applications used by a user is an important part of overall usability, helping users to feel confident and at ease when using a suite of products – no unexpected surprises. We have identified areas directly relevant to users and plan to introduce a number of design updates in SAP Fiori for web across our suite of products to further increase consistency.

The areas we have redesigned and which we plan to provide across our suite of products this year and next year are:

  • Shell bar (at the top of the user’s screen)
  • Navigation menu: side navigation (see Figure 3 below).
  • User menu
  • Notifications
  • Search in the shell bar

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition already supports the first four of these, you can have a look at them in part 2 of this series, in the section SAP Fiori Launchpad and Design Updates for Suite Consistency:

  • SAP UX Q3/2025 Update – Part 2: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 and SAP Fiori Launchpad.

As outlined in Part 1, SAP Build Work Zone standard edition also supports side navigation.

Find out more about these design updates here:

  • Upcoming Design Updates for the SAP Business Suite (SAP Fiori for Web).

We also provide designers with a refreshed new set of illustrations, to be used for illustrated messages. Figure 3 shows some examples.

Figure 3: Examples of new illustrations. Alt Text: On the left top three different size illustrations showing an ice cream cone fallen on the ground; bottom left an illustration of a globe with a magnifying glass, representing “search”. On the right an image of a list report showing the search illustration since no data has been selected.

 

News for Creating Web UIs

Extensibility made easy with the SAP Build Extensibility Wizard

Extending SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition is made much easier since we introduced the SAP Build Extensibility Wizard. The latest update introduces the ability to create an SAPUI5 adaptation project as a User Interface Extension.

Figure 4: Creating an SAPUI5 adaptation project as a User Interface Extension. Alt Text: Screenshot showing step 1 “Extension” task where users can select from a row of four cards “Custom Field”, “Custom Logic”, “Custom Process” and “User Interface Extension”. The latter has a subtext “Adapt the current application or extend it visually with a new application”. The latter two cards have a link “Manage SAP Build Projects” at the bottom. The bottom right shows two buttons “Next” and “Cancel”.

Learn more here:

  • SAP Build Extensibility Wizard for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.
  • Simplify SAPUI5 Code Extensions with the SAP Build Extensibility Wizard

Auto-fix of coding errors with UI5 linter

UI5 linter is the tool of choice to check your UI5 project for using best practices and replacement of deprecated SAPUI5 APIs. With UI5 linter v1.12.0, we are happy to announce the initial version of an autofix feature: Use the "--fix" argument to let UI5 linter apply fixes to your code automatically. Read more about it here:

  • Migrate your code with UI5 linter – Autofix has landed.

Legacy-free version of SAPUI5 available via cloud access

Once you have removed code which uses deprecated SAPUI5 APIs, you can try out the legacy-free version of SAPUI5 in the cloud, which has all deprecated code removed. Discover the benefits and how to try it out in this blog post:

  • Explore SAPUI5/OpenUI5 1.136.x-legacy-free.

Accessibility taken to the next level: WCAG 2.2 support

Accessibility is key to using SAP's business solutions. Adopting the latest standards gives applications a true cutting edge, ensuring that solutions are inclusive and meet the diverse needs of users globally. When creating apps with SAP Build and SAPUI5, developers can leverage the latest Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) 2.2.

For example, two of the key new requirements in the 2.2 version are:

  • The minimum target size of an interactive element now needs to be 24x24 px, so that users don’t accidentally activate a neighbouring element.
  • Each operation that can be performed by dragging can also be performed alternatively without dragging – so that people who cannot use a mouse to drag can still use the UI.

See more details:

  • SAPUI5 is Leading the Way in Accessibility with WCAG 2.2

SAP Fiori tools – open source, faster app creation, more AI

One of the most powerful recent innovations is the AI-powered project accelerator from SAP Fiori tools, which allows you to create a fully functional app with database tables, CDS-Views, OData service and a Fiori element list report UI based on a sketch of what you want. I introduced this in my Q1 update post from March. This can now be started from Joule in SAP Build Code. Also, it has been further enhanced, and is also available as open source, so that our developer community can make contributions themselves. Find out more here:

  • From idea to app: using AI-powered Project Accelerator to develop SAP Fiori apps
  • SAP Fiori Application Generator Available in Open Source

For those of you developing in ABAP, we have introduced the new quick SAP Fiori application generator to create and deploy simple SAP Fiori applications from ABAP Development Tools for Eclipse. Have a closer look:

  • Quickly Generate and Deploy SAP Fiori Apps from ABAP Development Tools for Eclipse

To get an overview of these plus some additional enhancements, have a look at:

  • SAP Fiori tools 2506 update – Open source, faster app creation, adaptation boost, AI enhancements.

Enhancements for SAP Fiori Elements with OData V4

We are continuously enhancing SAPUI5 and SAP Fiori elements. I have picked two enhancements to highlight here for developers using SAPUI5 and SAP Fiori elements on OData V4, which are covered in the following subsections:

  • Support for inline edit for object pages.
  • Support for the analytical table on the object page.

Support for inline edit for object pages

You can now develop object pages where users can directly edit fields within facets, without having to first press the “Edit” button and go into edit mode. Figure 5 shows an example from a test application.

Figure 5: Inline editing of fields in an object page with SAP Fiori elements for OData V4. Alt Text: A screenshot of part of an object page “Travel”, which is overall in display mode, but the field “Starting Date” has been selected and is editable, with a new entry made, and “Save” and “Cancel” icons next to the field.

Support for the analytical table on the object page

For applications where users need to be able to analyze the data in a table, for example grouping data and aggregating data, developers should use the analytical table rather than the responsive table.

These tables are often used for the “list” part of an SAP Fiori elements list report, which consists of a list and an object page for the details. Now, developers using SAPUI5 and SAP Fiori elements on OData V4 can include an analytical table into one of the facets of an object page. Figure 6 shows an example.

Figure 6: Analytical table in an object page with SAP Fiori elements for OData V4. Alt Text: A screenshot of an object page with a facet “Journal Entries (4)” which contains an analytical table, where the entries are grouped by “Case Journal Entry”. One of the groups is expanded, showing two lines. Below them the sum of the debit column is shown for the expanded group, and below that for the entire table.

Further Updates for SAPUI5

As I described in part 1 of this series, we have introduced a new option to preview an upcoming SAPUI5 version for SAP Build Work Zone. This capability aims to provide a controlled environment for evaluating SAPUI5 updates in SAP Build Work Zone, thereby avoiding immediate changes in production environments:

  • Introducing SAPUI5 Version Preview in SAP Build Work Zone.

Key users can create consistent text changes with SAPUI5 flexibility. I described this in the context of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition in part 2 of this series (section Key Users Can Rearrange ID and Description Within a Field or Column). They can also easily change the labels used, to fit terms established within the company. Read more about this here:

  • How Key Users Create Consistent Text Changes with SAPUI5 Flexibility.

SAPUI5 has reached a new milestone: it is now used on all 7 continents. Yes, we have reached Antarctica!

  • SAPUI5 adoption becoming more universal.

In case you have not updated your system for a while, then be aware that we are removing SAP Fiori themes Belize and Blue Crystal. Also, make sure that you are using the latest browser versions, which may mean ensuring that your users laptops and desktops are using newer operating system versions:

  • Upcoming Removal of SAP Fiori Themes Belize and Blue Crystal
  • Prevent an SAP Fiori / SAPUI5 Downtime — Check Your Browser Strategy Today!

To get a complete overview of all the enhancements in SAPUI5 including SAP Fiori elements, look at the UI5 demo kit. You’ll find some of the enhancements mentioned above listed under version 1.136.

  • What’s New in SAPUI5.

 

News for Mobile Designers and Developers

The main news for mobile designers are the new SAP Design System portal, which covers Android and iOS as well as the latest releases of the mobile Figma design kits for Android, iOS, WatchOs and WearOS.

Figure 7: The Android and iOS pages in the new SAP Design System portal. Alt Text: Both screenshots look the same, except for Android vs iOS text. The top has a “Get Started” section, with a row of cards to navigate to UI Elements, UI Kit, Development Documentation. Below that a “What’s New” section, with information about the latest release “SAP Fiori for Android version 25.8” and “…for iOS…”.

The best place to stay up-to-date with these latest enhancements is the respective What’s New section in the SAP Design System portal:

  • SAP BTP SDK for iOS 25.4: What’s new for SAP Fiori for iOS
  • SAP BTP SDK for Android 25.8 (design preview) and 25.4: What’s new for SAP Fiori for Android

Figure 8 shows two of the many new enhancements: the new illustrations mentioned earlier in the section on web UIs are also available for mobile, both for iOS and Android. The other example shown there is the updated date picker for Android, which now allows users to select date ranges.

Figure 8: On the left, an example of the new illustrated messages for mobile. On the right, date ranges can now be selected in the date picker for Android. Alt Text: The illustrated message is used in a pop-over. The illustration shows a sheet of paper with a tickmark, below that the text “You’re all caught up…” and two buttons “Add Task” and “Remind Me Later”. On the right two date screens are shown for the month of April: the left one has the 8th marked, the right one has the range from 8th to 16th marked.

Developers get new features with the latest releases of the mobile SDKs, as well as the the Mobile Development Kit (MDK) which is integrated into SAP Build Code. Here are links to find out more about them:

  • What’s new in Mobile development kit client 25.6, for example:
    • Support grouping in Object Table Control
    • Donut chart support
    • … and more.
  • Continuous Innovation in Mobile Design & Technology: SAP Fiori for Android and iOS 25.4
  • SAP BTP SDK for iOS: What’s New in 25.08
  • SAP BTP SDK for Android 25.4.0 is now available

 

Final words

As you can see from all seven posts in the series, we continue to progress rapidly with the user experience of our product portfolio, especially with regards to AI-assistance.

Part 1 of the series lists all the parts, and links to those parts that have already been published:

  • SAP UX Q3/2025 Update – Part 1: AI, Joule, SAP Build Work Zone, SAP Mobile Start.

Do keep posting your experiences and recommendations yourself in the SAP Community, with the SAP Fiori and/or the User Experience tag! In case you are wondering how to get a list of the most recent blog posts on SAP Fiori and User Experience in our new SAP Community, use these links:

  • Latest blog posts on SAP Fiori in the SAP Community.
  • Latest blog posts on User Experience in the SAP Community.

For general information on design at SAP and SAP Fiori, check out:

  • www.sap.com/design.
  • www.sap.com/fiori.
  • SAP Community: SAP Fiori topic page.

entry.title: Dashboard and Business AI Insights for SAP License Simulation and Analysis
entry.content:
Introduction

SAP has introduced the SAM4U solution, an excellent tool to gather data from SAP backend systems for the consolidation and analysis of users, engines, and HANA EE license consumption.

The Accelerator for SAM4U Adoption, available on SAP Store, provides extended analytics and simulation capabilities to view SAM4U data from new angles. It empowers customers moving to S/4HANA, S/4HANA Private Cloud, or already working under an SAP RISE contract to run different “what if” scenarios based on data extracted from their SAP system, helping them find the best approach to optimize SAP license consumption.

What Was Missing?

While SAM4U provides valuable transparency, customers often asked:

  • How do I see the potential savings?

  • How do I define a strategy for optimization?

  • Where exactly should I focus my cleanup efforts?

License optimization typically falls into three categories:

  • Fast optimization: achieved quickly with user data cleanup in SAP backend

  • Obtainable optimization: achievable in reasonable time with cleanup and role/profile tuning

  • Maximal optimization: the long-term goal, achieved when roles and authorizations are precisely aligned with actual usage

What was missing was clarity and insights to navigate these paths effectively.

How it is solved

The new release of the Accelerator for SAM4U Adoption brings two major updates:

  • Clarity through an extremely informative dashboard

  • Business AI insights powered by the Skybuffer AI platform, an SAP Business AI certified solution from SAP Store

The dashboard

This is the highlight. The dashboard presents clear KPIs on one page, helping to get insights into current estimated spending and estimated savings, following both fast and obtainable strategies.

 Pic. 1 The Dashboard

One of the central KPIs is License Optimization Potential, which shows the estimated current contract costs compared to optimized contract costs. The KPI highlights savings that can be achieved either through the fast users cleanup approach or the obtainable approach of cleaning up users and optimizing roles with the highest optimization potential.

 Pic. 2 License Optimization Potential

There are many other useful insights. For example, it shows how many authorization objects are not used at all. This is a target for maximal optimization and one reason it is not so easily obtainable. The lower the number, the better the authorizations are aligned with active usage.

 Pic. 3 Excess Authorization

The evaluation of maximal optimization is also visualized by the FUE Gap KPI:

 Pic. 4 FUE Gap - Authorization vs Active Usage

There is also a very helpful hint about SAP_ALL and SAP_NEW profiles still in use in production:

 Pic. 5 Users with Sensitive Authorization Profiles

The total number of roles and profiles that can be optimized and the savings this brings are also clearly summarized:

 Pic. 6 Excess Roles

The insights

Business AI insights in the dashboard bring extra clarity and understanding. For example, they show the fast optimization saving potential and provide clear explanations and strategies on how to reach it:

Pic. 7 Business AI Insights

AI recommendations are also available for obtainable or maximal optimization:

 Pic. 8 Max and Obtainable Optimization

Effectively, this functions as a personal SAP License Analysis and Optimization consultant, virtualized and trained to understand the organization’s own data.

The AI Assistant is always there, and expanding its knowledge base is straightforward through the Skybuffer AI platform. For example, it can present the top 10 roles for optimization or provide additional information related to SAP licensing:

 Pic. 9 Top 10 Roles for Optimization

Of course, all the well-established simulation and analysis tools of the Accelerator remain available. With the new release, they work even better, helping to test and simulate the AI Assistant’s recommendations.

Conclusion

The Accelerator for SAM4U Adoption now provides one of the most powerful toolsets on the market to analyze and optimize SAP users and engines licenses independently. It helps avoid the significant costs of SAP license optimization consulting and delivers deep insights into user and engine data. This comes without the need for a complex SAM4U installation and without spending time and money on consulting services that quickly become outdated.

What to do next?

Running SAP under a RISE contract? Use the dashboard and Business AI insights at least once per month to avoid FUE consumption increases and surprises. Train your team with the solution and the organization will not face unpredictable growth of SAP license consumption. Leave consulting for the exceptional case when the company grows faster than its SAP role set. 😉

entry.title: Simulation for SAM4U Solution: Flexibility with the Accelerator for SAM4U Adoption
entry.content:
When adopting SAP SAM4U, one of the biggest challenges customers face is handling role, profile, and authorization changes without disrupting production. This is where the Accelerator for SAM4U Adoption brings real value, thanks to its simulation capabilities.

What Customers Expect from Authorization Simulation

With the simulation, customers get the ability to:

  • Log changes at the role or profile level on the system dataset.
  • Track and review roles and profiles that have been modified.
  • Revert changes at the role or profile level, either all at once or individually.
  • Modify user-to-role or user-to-profile assignments.
  • Perform mass unassignments of roles and profiles (e.g., removing SAP_ALL or SAP_NEW).
  • Identify and review changes made to users.
  • Revert user assignments back to their original state when needed.

 Pic. 01 Roles and Profiles Changes Tracking

 Pic. 02 Roles and Profiles Mass Unassignment

 Pic. 03 Changes to the Role Detailed Review

But that’s not all! The real power lies in managing simulation snapshots.

 Pic. 04 Snapshots of Simulations on the System’s Dataset Level

Why Simulation Snapshots Matter

Simulation snapshots are created at the system dataset level, allowing you to:

  • Save changes without applying them directly in production.
  • Create new consolidations from modified datasets.
  • Avoid repetitive, time-consuming rework when changes cannot be applied immediately.

Example: Working with Two Systems in Consolidation

Imagine you are analyzing two systems in a consolidation project. You make changes to roles and users in both systems. However, due to restrictions, you cannot yet apply changes in System A.

Without losing your work, you can:

  • Create a new consolidation using the dataset from System A and the modified snapshot from System B.
  • Or temporarily move the snapshot from System A into the dataset, and later reapply those changes when they are ready for production.

 Pic. 05 The Power of Management Snapshots and Datasets that are Used in Consolidation

This flexibility ensures you never have to redo your work and can manage changes efficiently.

Why Customers Prefer the Accelerator for SAM4U Adoption

Customers appreciate the simulation feature because it provides:

  • System-level flexibility to manage changes.
  • Easy-to-handle snapshots that can be created, reviewed, reverted, and reused.
  • No duplication of effort, once a change is made, it is saved and can be reapplied.
  • Reliable validation, you can reload fresh production data and check if changes were successfully implemented.

If changes were tracked only at the consolidation level, fresh data from the system would overwrite them. This is why the Accelerator focuses on system snapshots, giving customers full control to experiment, validate, and roll back whenever needed.

 Pic.06 Accelerator for SAM4U Adoption Dashboard for Simulation Results Analysis

With the Accelerator for SAM4U Adoption, simulation becomes not just a test environment, but a strategic tool for efficient and risk-free SAM4U adoption.

entry.title: 5 Tips for Getting Started with the SAP Fiori for Web UI Kit
entry.content:
The SAP Fiori for Web UI Kit is your go-to resource for creating consistent, efficient, and accessible user interfaces. The kit helps you design faster without starting from scratch.

Here are five helpful tips to get started and design with confidence:


1. Explore the full component library first 

Before jumping into design work, begin with the design foundations separately, such as color, typography, and shadows. Understanding these basics early on will help you make better, more consistent decisions throughout your work. You’ll also find SAP icons and product illustrations integrated directly into the kit. 

Once you're familiar with the foundations, take time to explore the full set of components included in the file. The UI kit provides a wide range of ready-made elements, scalable and fully aligned with SAP’s design principles, all in one place. 


 2. Use variables to switch between themes easily 

In the SAP Fiori for Web UI Kit, variables control core style properties such as colors, typography, and spacing. 

The kit includes support for multiple themes that reflect SAP’s visual language in different environments. The default light theme is called Morning Horizon, and for low-light settings, the Evening Horizon theme provides a dark mode alternative. 



Using variables, you can switch between these themes easily within your Figma file. This lets you preview how your designs will look across different user preferences without rebuilding components from scratch. 


3. Use the Slot for content placement 

Some components, such as Dialogs or Cards, include a Slot - a clearly marked area (highlighted in orange) where you can insert your own content, like text, icons, or buttons, while keeping the original structure and behavior intact. 

To use it, simply select the Slot layer in the component and replace it with your own content using the “Swap instance” option in the right-hand panel. There’s no need to detach the component, your changes will stay consistent and maintain the design integrity. 
 

 
Using the Slot keeps your designs flexible, editable, and easy to maintain. 

 

4. Keep your file organized and use naming conventions 

Maintaining a well-organized file helps you and your team navigate and manage designs efficiently. Use clear naming conventions for frames, components, and layers so it’s easy to find and update elements later. This practice saves time and reduces errors, especially as your designs grow in complexity. 
 



5. Stay in sync with releases 

The SAP Fiori for Web UI Kit is actively maintained and regularly improved with new components, updates, and refinements based on user feedback. To stay up to date, keep an eye on official announcements and communications from the SAP Design team.  You can find the latest releases and enhancements on our SAP Design System Portal “What’s New” page. 

The SAP Fiori for Web UI Kit gives you more than a set of components, it provides a solid foundation for building enterprise-ready designs that scale.

entry.title: Introducing SAP Fiori for Android/iOS 25.8: Innovative Enhancements for Android and iOS
entry.content:
SAP Fiori continues to advance its technological offerings with the release of SAP BTP SDK version 25.8, featuring exciting updates for both Android and iOS. This release introduces a suite of new capabilities as well as upgrades to current features, enhancing user experiences on business apps.

New in SAP Fiori for Android 25.8

In the following section, we’ll give you a brief overview about everything that’s new in SAP Fiori for Android 25.8.

Circular In-Place Progress Indicator

The circular in-place progress indicator displays the status of ongoing processes when loading is initiated by a button. An indicator within the button shows the loading state. The progress indicator has been enhanced to allow customization of the icon button so that once loading is finished, the icon button can be changed to a different icon.

For more information, check out the Circular Progress Indicator article in the SAP Fiori for Android design guidelines.

Object cell with a circular progress indicator

Illustrated Message

The illustrated message component, which helps communicate empty, error, and success states through a combination of engaging illustrations, solution-oriented messages, and a conversational tone, has been updated with new illustration assets.

To learn more about this component, refer to Illustrated Message.

Illustrated message with the new “empty task” illustration

Native File Viewer

The native file viewer, which allows users to preview files, now supports viewing password-protected PDFs by prompting them to enter a password in a dialog before the file is displayed, expanding accessibility and document control within apps.

For more information, check out Native File Viewer.

Password-protected PDF files in native file viewer

Picker Form Cell

The picker form cell, used for making date and time-based selections, is now available for Jetpack Compose.

See Date and Time Picker Form Cell for more information.

Date picker form cell with Horizon tonal color option

Stepper Form Cell

The stepper form cell and the nested stepper control, which allow users to incrementally increase or decrease a select value, are now available for Jetpack Compose.

Check out the Stepper Form Cell guideline article to learn more.

Stepper form cell in horizontal layout (top) and vertical layout (bottom)

Text Input Form Cell

Text input form cells have been enhanced to provide currency support, allowing users to enter currency values in single property form cells.  The form cells now feature ISO codes  that automatically format the text input with the corresponding currency symbol.

For more information, refer to Text Inputs.

 

New in SAP Fiori for iOS 25.8

Check out what's new in SAP Fiori for Android 25.8. 

Illustrated Message

Just like the Android equivalent, the illustrated message component has been updated with new illustration assets to help communicate empty, error, and success states with engaging illustrations.

Learn more about this component in the Illustrated Message SAP Fiori for iOS guideline article.

Illustrated message in different containers

Modals and Sheets

We have added new guideline articles for modality and sheets that cover all types of modals and sheets, including but not limited to full-screen modals, non-modal sheets, action sheets, popovers, and form sheets.

For more information, refer to Modality and Sheets.

Modal sheet 

Pickers

The date range picker is now supported as a picker form cell, enabling the triggering of the date range selection component.

Take a look at the Pickers guideline article for more information. 

Date range picker

Text Inputs

Text inputs now come with currency support via a new view modifier, enabling display of the ISO code in the text input label, showing the currency symbol after editing, and applying localized formatting using native Apple APIs and formatters.

Check out Text Inputs to view more details.

Text input - single property form cell with currency field support

entry.title: Introducing Horizon Themes and Usability Enhancements in SAP Analytics Cloud
entry.content:

We are excited to announce the introduction of the Horizon themes in SAP Analytics Cloud a modern, cohesive visual language aligned across SAP’s product suite. You will have access to Morning and Evening Horizon, the light and dark themes as well as to the high contrast white and black themes.

This release also brings a series of improvements to the side navigation, user profile, user settings, and the search, making it easier than ever to find insights and personalize your application.

 

Horizon Themes: Modern, Accessible, and Unified

The introduction of Horizon themes marks the next step in our user experience journey. These themes feature clean lines, contemporary color palettes, and improved contrasts, resulting in visually appealing UI that remain comfortable for extended work sessions. Accessibility is at the heart of Horizon, with thoughtful color selections and focus indicators for every user. The experience remains consistent as you move between SAP Analytics Cloud and other SAP solutions, offering a unified interface that supports productivity and ease of use. Personalize your experience by choosing from light, dark, and high contrast theme variants—simply head to your user settings to select your preferred look.

The Belize theme will remain the default in Q4 and continue to be available for the next few quarters. Looking ahead, Horizon will become the standard theme in the first half of 2026. If you’d like to enable Horizon for your organization sooner, simply navigate to the administration section under default appearance to set Horizon as your tenant’s default theme.

 

Improved User Profile and Settings

The user profile and settings have been reimagined to put key information and settings at your fingertips. Instantly access your account details, profile image, and settings in one clear and organized dialog. Additionally, the “About” section is now conveniently located within your user profile making key information more accessible whenever you need it.

 

Simplified and Adaptive Side Navigation

The redesigned side navigation bar logically organizes content and tools for easy access. Collapsible sections expand your workspace, and in collapsed view, hovering over each symbol shows module names to help you quickly find what you need.

 

More Convenient Search

The search now features autocomplete, making it noticeably more convenient and user-friendly. As you begin typing, relevant suggestions appear instantly, streamlining the process of finding models, stories, and files. This enhancement helps you locate what you need more efficiently, even if you can’t recall exact names, ensuring a smoother search experience.

These updates are based on user feedback and extensive research, reflecting SAP’s commitment to delivering an analytics platform that is powerful, accessible, and a pleasure to use. The Horizon themes and experience enhancements aim to reduce friction, promote creativity, and empower you to shape insights in a visually appealing and highly functional space.

 

What's Next

You can continue to style your SAP Analytics Cloud Stories independently, as the story theme mechanism will remain unchanged and won't follow the overall SAC theme.

With the Q1 2026 release, we plan to update the preferences for new stories and make the Horizon Morning theme available in every story; both Morning and Evening Horizon themes are currently available on GitHub.

The new Horizon themes and user experience improvements will be available mid-November in the Q4 2025 SAP Analytics Cloud release.

If you have feedback on the Horizon themes or the planned story theme updates, please reach out to me by message or in the comments.

entry.title: How to unassign an Authorization Package from an S-user ID in SAP for Me
entry.content:
As an administrator managing user access in SAP for Me is a critical part of maintaining system security and operational efficiency. Whether you're onboarding new users as an admin, or adjusting access for existing ones, knowing how to properly assign and revoke authorization packages is essential. 

 

Why This Matters?

Authorization packages define what an S-user ID can access within the SAP for Me ecosystem—from support cases to license data, viewing systems, software download, etc. Keeping these permissions up to date ensures compliance, prevents unauthorized access, and streamlines user roles across your organization.

 

Steps:  

  1. Log in to SAP for Me using your S-user ID and password.  
  2.  In the SAP for Me homepage, click on “Users & Contacts” tab under Dashboard at the left side of your screen.  
  3. Then, click on “Manage Users & Authorization” card. Or simply go to User Management.  
  4. Under the list of users, find the S-user ID to unassign the authorization package from. Or simply use the search field to search for the specific S-user ID and click on the magnifying glass to search.  
  5. Click on the user/S-user ID (not the checkbox).
  6. Click on the EXISTING AUTHORIZATION PACKAGES tab.  
  7. Click the Edit (Pencil) icon on the top right of that section. 
  8. Click on the checkbox in front of the Authorization Package(s) to be removed. 
  9. Click OK. 
  10. Click Save on the top right of the EXISTING AUTHORIZATION PACKAGES section. 

     

For more details, please refer to Knowledge Base Article: 2878696 - How to unassign an Authorization Package from an S-user ID - SAP for Me.
